Summary I am a high-energy PhD candidate with experience solving real-world engineering problems.  
 
My background includes academic and industrial research experience in computational mathematics, data science, fluid mechanics, petroleum and aerospace engineering.  
 
I am passionate about building theoretically and computationally sound tools that leverage optimization, machine learning, statistical learning, PDEs, reservoir simulation.  
 
I enjoy working in and leading high-energy interdisciplinary teams, writing efficient code, and solving challenging problems.  Summary I am a high-energy PhD candidate with experience solving real-world engineering problems.

Summary Looking at the human part of HCI, focusing on social presence and connectedness to out-group members through diverse media formats. Working on multitasking research, social networking and emotions with the hope of increasing compassion through interactive digital media.  
 
Specialties: Research Design, Ethnographic Methods, Information Architect, User Interface Design, Content Writing and Editing, Web Development, Graphic Design. Technically proficient in XHTML, HTML, CSS, SPSS, R, Windows 98 + XP, Mac OSX, Microsoft Office, Excel, Word, Powerpoint, Visio, FrontPage, Adobe Photoshop, Illustrator, Dreamweaver, Fireworks, LaTeX (text-formatting program), Wordpress and RSS feeds. Working knowledge of the ASP.NET framework and Visual Studio. RA under Cliff Nass, TA for Bailenson's COMM 106, and Nass's COMM 1A. Adjunct Professor Stanford University June 2013  –  September 2013  (4 months) EDUC 313 Su13-COMM-107S-01 This course will draw on research regarding behavioral, cognitive, and physiological indicators and predictors of compassion, as well as computer-mediated communication, intimate and ubiquitous computing, social networking, and multitasking to better understand how interactive digital media affects compassionate behaviors, including altruism and helping. For their final project, students will either (1) propose an experiment for future research investigating compassion in HCI, or (2) propose a design change for an extant technology to engender compassionate responses. Adjunct Professor of Poetics New College of California January 2006  –  May 2006  (5 months) Developed syllabus for and taught course entitled "Finding Duende: The Dark Side of Poetry" - "Drawing from Lorca’s “Theory and Play of the Duende” and Pablo Neruda’s short essay “Toward an Impure Poetry,” this course seeks to relate the indefinable essence of duende, the bedeviling passion invoked while writing a strong type of poetry. Experience PhD Candidate Stanford University June 2011  – Present (4 years 3 months) Research advised by Professor Allison Okamura. Funding through an NRI-Large collaborative research grant entitled, "Multilateral Manipulation by Human-Robot Collaborative Systems". Multilateral manipulation is when a human operator controls one or more robot manipulators in partnership with one or more controllers. My research focuses on surgical applications of this human-centered autonomy. Completed work includes design of a software framework capable of supporting numerous collaboration strategies between a human and autonomous agent.  
 
This framework's first extension was to an inclusion segmentation task. Examples of collaboration strategies implemented include a fully autonomous algorithm, whereby numerous machine learning algorithms localize the hard inclusion, to supervised control, to pure teleoperation, shared control, and traded control. Results indicated tradeoffs in sensitivity, specificity, duration of experiment, and safety implications. This work used commercial Phantom haptic devices (Geomagic, Morrisville, NC, USA).  
 
Most recently this work has been extended to a debridement task implemented on the RAVEN surgical platform (Applied Dexterity, Seattle, WA, USA) . Current work combines the surgical sub-tasks already investigated into an entire surgical procedure, whereby under a variety of collaboration models a human and a robotic agent can explore an artificial tissue for hard inclusions, cut its skin, and excise any hard inclusions detected. I am implementing this task on the da Vinci Research Kit (Intuitive Surgical, Sunnyvale, CA, USA). Navigation Intern Intuitive Surgical June 2014  – Present (1 year 3 months) Working in the emerging technologies division. Investigated methods to utilize an advanced medical imaging technique to perform non-rigid registration of deformable anatomy during surgical procedures. The non-rigid registration will be used as ground truth for a virtual deformable model of the target anatomy. This work comprised of investigating and when necessary prototyping numerous algorithms for segmentation, skeletonization, and non-rigid registration. This work was full time during the summer of 2014 with reduced hours afterwards. Human Interface Design Engineering Intern Intuitive Surgical June 2013  –  June 2014  (1 year 1 month) Sunneyvale Worked in the emerging technologies division. Designed and implemented an exhaustive study interfacing a variety of human input devices (HIDs) to a system currently in development. During the summer of 2013 I worked full time, with the internship culminating with an in-vivo testing of select HIDs with clinicians. Limited hours during the following academic year included expanding HID features. Research Assistant Johns Hopkins University June 2010  –  May 2011  (1 year) Baltimore, Maryland Research advised by Professor Louis Whitcomb, Professor Allison Okamura, and Professor Noah Cowan on a rotating basis. This worked involved (1) testing and validating performance of an inertial measurement unit used on an autonomous underwater vehicle with Professor Whitcomb, (2) investigating design changes of the captain drive in a commercial haptic device for increased performance with Professor Okamura, and (3) investigating the coupling between the visual and electroreception channels in weakly electric fish with Professor Cowan. Software Intern Disney's Interactive Media Group June 2009  –  May 2010  (1 year) Wrote ActionScript 3.0 code compiled with Flex Builder 3/4 in an object-oriented programming environment to contribute towards the create portal found at Disney.com/create. Individual tasks included performance cleanup, extensive work with the geometry library, numerous bug fixes, unit tests, focus group testing, and feature enhancements. Research Assistant University of Colorado at Boulder January 2007  –  December 2008  (2 years) Boulder, Colorado Research advised by Professor Todd Murphey (now at Northwestern University) in the Robotics and Controls Laboratory. Used variational integrators to model constrained cables and other systems subject to holonomic constraints. Research Assistant University of Southern California June 2008  –  August 2008  (3 months) Los Angeles, CA Research advised by Professor Francisco Valero-Cuevas in the Biomechanics Laboratory. This work used expanded on the research I conducted at University of Colorado at Boulder and applied variational integrators to model the tendon topology of the finger. A variety of different suspected topologies were simulated and their I used variational methods to model the dynamics of the tendon topology of the finger subject to various loads. Peace Corps Education Volunteer Peace Corps September 2005  –  December 2007  (2 years 4 months) •	Taught classes of approximately 60 students each at Jecúa Secondary School and worked in partnership on extra curricular activities at Chinhamapere Secondary School. 
•	Taught biology to secondary school students, including the topics of cellular biology, plant biology, environmental care, HIV/AIDS prevention and general health information. 
•	Instructed professors in the basic use of computer programs such as Microsoft Windows operating system: Word, Excel, and PowerPoint. In addition, I introduced a program that helped cut scheduling time from weeks to a day.  
•	Wrote a basic “How to Home Improvement” manual using basic available resources.  
•	Organized and directed the planning and completion of two regional Science Fairs that brought students from approximately 25 schools and 7 provinces together to compete. This required organizing schools and working with the Ministry of Education and Culture. 
•	Wrote and compiled in Portuguese a resource manual for schools explaining how to start and run school level science fairs. 
•	Organized and directed the planning and completion of a Provincial English Theater Competition that brought students from approximately 13 schools around the province of Manica together to compete. This required the organizing schools and working with the Ministry of Education and Culture. 
•	Wrote and compiled a resource manual for starting and running a provincial English Theater Competitions. 
•	Participated in the Jovens para Mundança e Acção (JOMA) with a group of 12 secondary school students. Activities included journalism, painting murals, school clean-up/improvement, HIV/AIDS prevention activities and gender equality discussions. 
•	A member and developer of material for the Peace Corps Peer Support Network which sought to help improve volunteer’s time, cultural adjustment and work in Mozambique. Summary I recently graduated top of my year in Economics from the University of Oxford, where I read PPE at Balliol College. I was awarded the Hicks and Webb Medley Prize, the John Hicks Foundation Prize, and was elected to the James Hall Scholarship. 
 
I have previously worked as Senior Economic Advisor to David Ruffley MP, and as an economic researcher for Jon Moynihan OBE, Executive Chairman of PA Consulting Group. 
 
I have also worked as South Asia Correspondent for The Economist, interned on the Civil Service Fast Stream and at Deutsche Bank, and co-founded and edited a Guardian Student Publication of the Year shortlisted magazine. 
 
At Balliol I was the Senior Organ Scholar (Director of Music), and President of the Arnold & Brackenbury Society.

Specialties: Economics, Politics, Philosophy, Public Policy, Afghanistan, Pakistan, South Asia, Foreign Policy, Religion, Technology, Journalism, Publishing, Communication, Writing, Public Speaking, Business, Education Experience PhD Candidate Stanford University September 2014  – Present (1 year) Stanford, CA Research Associate Institute for Fiscal Studies August 2014  – Present (1 year 1 month) Research Economist Institute for Fiscal Studies September 2013  –  August 2014  (1 year) London Graduate student MIT August 2012  –  August 2013  (1 year 1 month) Cambridge, MA Economic Analyst Office of Jon Moynihan OBE January 2012  –  April 2012  (4 months) London, United Kingdom I worked one-on-one with the Executive Chairman of PA Consulting Group to create a presentation on ‘The Continued Economic Decline of the West’, a data-driven survey of the key challenges facing Western economies. 
 
I interpreted complex econometric models to draw out insights and policy recommendations for a non-specialist audience, and surveyed officials at the Bank of England, HM Treasury, IMF, OECD, BLS and others to produce a high-level analysis of quantitative easing, debt and deleveraging, employment flows, and other global macro trends. 
 
Subsequently, I ran a social media marketing campaign which resulted in Mr Moynihan being invited to write an Op-Ed for The Times, stories in Business Insider and The Atlantic, and interviews in ÉPOCA (most widely read magazine in Brazil) and Le Nouvel Observateur (most widely read magazine in France). Senior Economic Advisor House of Commons September 2011  –  December 2011  (4 months) London, United Kingdom I advised a senior Member of Parliament on macroeconomics, fiscal and monetary policy, and supported the Member in their work on the Treasury Select Committee and the Draft Financial Services Bill Joint Committee. 
 
I also drafted articles for the national press, wrote speeches, and liaised with economic policymakers, think tanks and journalists in the UK and abroad. Co-Founder and Editor The Alligator Online October 2008  –  August 2011  (2 years 11 months) I co-founded and edited the groundbreaking online magazine The Alligator, a platform for Oxford students and guest writers to publish professional-grade articles and multimedia. 
 
I helped recruit a network of contributors and designers currently numbering more than 250, and, with the rest of the Executive Team, co-ordinated fundraising, launching, marketing, legal and editorial work. 
 
I also headed up The Alligator's Multimedia Unit, and have conducted video interviews with, among others, Martin Sheen and Richard Schiff, Bamir Topi (then President of Albania), John Micklethwait (then Editor-in-Chief of The Economist), Baroness Pauline Neville-Jones (then Minister of State for Security and Counter Terrorism), Bishop Michael Nazir-Ali (which interview was subsequently published by The Times), and General Sir Mike Jackson (formerly Chief of the General Staff). 
 
In September 2010, The Alligator was shortlisted for Guardian Student Publication of the Year. Senior Organ Scholar Balliol College, Oxford October 2008  –  June 2011  (2 years 9 months) As Senior Organ Scholar, I acted as Balliol's Director of Music, and so combined my academic studies with running the college's Chapel Choir. 
 
This involved the recruitment of choristers, choral training and development, conducting, playing the organ, working with the Chaplain and other members of the Chapel community, putting on large-scale concerts, and arranging international tours. 
 
In March 2010 I directed a sell-out performance of Bruckner's Mass No. 2 in E Minor, and in December I led a successful tour to Kraków, Poland. Fast Stream Intern UK Government July 2010  –  September 2010  (3 months) I worked with senior civil servants and external consultants on the Business Control agenda in the Department for Work and Pensions, performing detailed analysis on the running of the organisation and leading cultural change throughout the 110,000-strong workforce. 
 
My most significant achievement was my work on corporate ethics, which was entirely self-directed. I performed detailed research in academic business journals and books, conducted focus groups with employees throughout the organisation, and undertook quantitative and qualitative studies of internal behaviours, policies and communications, to develop a comprehensive assessment and set of recommendations for the Department. I secured a personal endorsement of my work from the Secretary of State, and the presentation I created and delivered to my manager was so compelling that I was invited to repeat it for the Division's Executive Team, and subsequently for the Finance Director General. 
 
I also used my position within government to secure a large number of individual meetings with senior civil servants and government ministers working in my fields of interest. In particular, I spent days shadowing people as diverse as the Prime Minister's Chief Economic Adviser and Lord Freud, the Minister for Welfare Reform, and arranged one-on-one meetings with the Deputy Chief of the Defence Staff, the Prime Minister's Head of Afghanistan Comms, the FCO's lead on the SDSR, the Permanent Secretary at HM Treasury, and many others - as well as an entire afternoon with Sir Gus O'Donnell, Cabinet Secretary and Head of the Civil Service. Annual Fund Campaign Officer Balliol College, Oxford June 2010  –  July 2010  (2 months) In a telephone campaign, I personally raised almost £15,000 from Old Members as diverse as international television executives, ambassadors, and retired academics. South Asia Correspondent The Economist September 2009  –  March 2010  (7 months) In September 2009 I travelled to Afghanistan and the tribal areas of Pakistan as a freelance correspondent. 
 
Before my trip, I negotiated a place on a "Surviving Hostile Regions" course, run by SAS soldiers for BBC journalists and FCO officials, for which I gained a BTEC Level 4 professional qualification. I also spent time studying one of the local languages, Dari, and arranged to stay with an Afghan family in London to improve my conversation skills and cultural awareness. 
 
In country, I met with everyone from Taliban students at a madrassa to senior ISAF commanders and UN diplomats. 
 
I wrote a three part series on Afghanistan and Pakistan for The Economist, which was published in March 2010. 
 
Subsequently, I was invited to advise British Military Intelligence in a formal capacity. Private Tutor N/A December 2008  –  March 2010  (1 year 4 months) I privately tutored a number of individuals for senior school scholarships, Common Entrance, and GCSEs. 
 
I attracted clients entirely through word of mouth, and coached pupils one-on-one in Mathematics, English, History, Geography, Latin, and Ancient Greek. Guest Lecturer, British Military Intelligence British Army January 2010  –  January 2010  (1 month) After traveling to Afghanistan and Pakistan, I was invited to advise senior members of the British Army on counterinsurgency strategy. Investment Banking Division Intern Deutsche Bank March 2009  –  April 2009  (2 months) I interned on Deutsche Bank's highly competitive "Spring into Banking" programme for first year undergraduates. 
 
I specialised in Corporate Finance, spending time on the FIG and TMT desks. I also participated in a day-long "Introduction to the City" seminar, and took part in networking and team building workshops. Founder, CEO and Editor-in-Chief The Falopian September 2006  –  July 2008  (1 year 11 months) I founded The Falopian, a satirical magazine, as a pupil at Shrewsbury School. 
 
I overcame considerable institutional obstacles to publish a first issue, and subsequently recruited a 15-strong writing and graphics team. 
 
I negotiated advertising deals with local businesses to fund professional printing, and made a profit of £500+ on each further issue. Broadcast Journalism Intern BBC August 2006  –  August 2006  (1 month) I worked in the BBC's Midlands Today studios, researching stories, observing editorial meetings, and assisting on shoots and live broadcasts. Researcher House of Commons July 2006  –  July 2006  (1 month) I interned for the Conservative MP Bill Wiggin, the representative for Leominster and then Shadow Minister for Agriculture & Fisheries. 
 
I researched material for Parliamentary questions and drafted detailed correspondence with constituents and government ministers. Summary Currently a PhD Candidate at Stanford University, focusing on MEMS (microelectromechanical systems) sensor design, fabrication, and characterization. The focus of my research is in failure analysis (fatigue and adhesion), as well as sensor fusion of multiple sensors in a single-chip co-fabricated platform.  
 
I am extremely comfortable in a collaborative laboratory and testing environment, where critical thinking, prototyping, and characterization are needed with fast-turnaround. I have shown with great results (publications) the ability to efficiently bring multiple parties’ ideas together to achieve a broader goal of creating higher performance engineering systems, and the ability to maintain these ongoing relationships for further future improvements. 
 
Expertise:  
• Sensor characterization and integration  
• MEMS (micro electromechanical systems) sensor design and fabrication  
• Embedded mechatronic systems  
• Machine design/prototyping

Summary Chris is a design professional, design educator, and design researcher in the areas of both Architecture and Infrastructure design. 
 
Upon graduating from North Carolina State University, Chris joined the New York office of Richard Meier & Partners where he assisted the design development of both competition entries and commissions. The majority of Chris' tenure spanned the multiple phases of design and construction administration of the 173 / 176 Perry Street residential towers located in Manhattan. 
 
Chris relocated to Tucson AZ in 2002 and worked for Rick Joy Architects as a project / construction manager for a private residence in Tucson’s Pima Canyon. At Rob Paulus Architects, Chris assisted the development of the Ice House Lofts and managed projects including Barrio Metalico and St. Andrews Gospel Hall. While an Associate with RPA, Chris was also an Adjunct Lecturer at the University of Arizona. 
 
In Fall 2005, Chris joined the University of Nebraska College of Architecture where he regularly teaches undergraduate and graduate design studios, courses in Design Methodology and Modern Craft, and advises Design Thesis. He is a former Coordinator of the Internship program, a past Chair of the Hyde Lecture series, a past President of the Larsen Tractor Museum, and was the 2008-2010 Steward Professor in Sustainable Design. In Spring 2013, Chris coordinated the "London | 2013" Program where his research prompted coursework on Hybridized Urban Infrastructures. 
 
In Fall 2013, Chris began a Leave for Doctoral Study and is currently a PhD candidate at Stanford University in the Mechanical Engineering Design Group. As a Research Assistant for Professor Larry Leifer PhD in the Stanford University Center for Design Research, Chris is able to advance his research agenda in design methodology of the built environment and is currently researching design requirements for next-generation infrastructure types for New York City NY and San Francisco CA. He is a former Coordinator of the Internship program, a past Chair of the Hyde Lecture series, a past President of the Larsen Tractor Museum, and was the 2008-2010 Steward Professor in Sustainable Design. In Spring 2013, Chris coordinated the "London | 2013" Program where his research prompted coursework on Hybridized Urban Infrastructures. 
 
In Fall 2013, Chris began a Leave for Doctoral Study and is currently a PhD candidate at Stanford University in the Mechanical Engineering Design Group. As a Research Assistant for Professor Larry Leifer PhD in the Stanford University Center for Design Research, Chris is able to advance his research agenda in design methodology of the built environment and is currently researching design requirements for next-generation infrastructure types for New York City NY and San Francisco CA. Chris is a design professional, design educator, and design researcher in the areas of both Architecture and Infrastructure design.

Experience Research Coordinator, "Design-X Resilience" Center for Design Research | Stanford University September 2013  – Present (2 years) Palo Alto CA "Design-X Resilience"​ is an initiative dedicated to design problems whose solutions operate in unforeseeable future contexts different from those in which they were originally designed. These future contexts are proving to be behaviorally unpredictable and oftentimes introduce a failure to a design solution. By examining the relationships between context-specific design solutions and the volatile contexts in which they operate, we find a new opportunity for user-centered research and design. 
 
An interest in Resilience accepts the possibility of failure, which requires an intellectual expansion for a professional community that has for decades designed for Robustness. Historically, robust solutions have required operational persistence in the face of any failure mode, as failure would reflect poorly on the engineered solution, the engineering service delivered, and the engineers themselves. The qualities of strength, durability, and the ability to resist all opposing forces are by themselves no longer of exclusive importance. Today, the qualities of absorption, adaptability, operational dexterity and redundancy are of primary importance. 
 
Resilience empowers solutions to return to normalized levels of performance after experiencing failure. Resilient design incorporates feature sets that anticipate future failure, and possess inherent qualities that accelerate recovery. It is within these periods of recovery and percentages of return that resilience can be measured -- Whereas robust solutions break, resilient solutions rebound.  
 
Designing for Resilience reorganizes and reprioritizes the design requirements for forthcoming design solutions, and this is true across multiple types of problems, whether the design of our most densely-populated cities or handheld medical devices. Projects under this initiative have included the 2015 US Department of Energy Solar Decathlon competition, "House+,"​ and "Secondary Cross-Over Infrastructures" for San Francisco CA.

Summary I am a PhD candidate at Stanford University, specializing in computer systems and software security, advised by Prof. Dan Boneh. My recent publication is on eavesdropping on speech using the gyroscopes in mobile devices. I have many years of software development experience, as a self-employed consultant, one of the first engineers in a start-up and serving several years in an elite technological unit of the IDF intelligence branch. For almost a year and a half I have managed a team of eight researchers and developers in the field of software security and networking. I am passionate about good system architecture, and secure design.
